commit_message:
Fix missing reference

Fix a warning that security-boundaries-and-threats-attack-types could
not be found. We need to use a figure to reference an object.

Fix reference as well to use xref.

Change-Id: Idf25ce9960082224bc73e36b7388ee50908f01fc

commit_message:
Include all strings for translations.

Building should not handle our tags, thus set *all* tags at once so that
all files get included in the po files.

Change-Id: I061988451543caea926cc60a3517203fc1807298
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/56/170356/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OPTS="" # We need to build guides with all tags so that all strings get # extracted. if [ "$DOCNAME" = "playground-user-guide" ] ; then OPTS="-t user_only -t admin_only" fi sphinx-build $OPTS -b gettext doc/$DOCNAME/source/ doc/$DOCNAME/source/locale/

subject: Proxy delete method
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-13 19:13:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/86054e628140cac64f860082cecf954a67da96e7', 'message': "Proxy delete method

This change introduces a common delete API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around deleting a resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to deleting a server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls delete on it,
after obtaining the canonical resource for that value out of
Resource.from_id.

Since this temporarily involves two separate proxy delete APIs, I've
called the test verify_delete2. When we apply it everywhere in a mass
change, we will go back to one test.

Change-Id: I755c57e9bd9cec597a5bcf84c527e7bd6d710fb3
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-13 20:17:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/7e9052037a47324826aae703ff918b29e2f0d28a', 'message': "Proxy delete method

This change introduces a common delete API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around deleting a resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to deleting a server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls delete on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical for that value out of
Resource.get_id.

Since this temporarily involves two separate proxy delete APIs, I've
called the test verify_delete2. When we apply it everywhere in a mass

"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-03-14 03:53:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/f67eeff703f08be1210f8bfa379e945eb6a205ca', 'message': "Proxy delete method

This change introduces a common delete API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around deleting a resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to deleting a server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls delete on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. Additionally, a decorator has been added that
checks if resources that are passed to it are of the appropriate type
for that operation. For example, this will raise ValueError if you try
to call delete_server with a flavor, rather than making the call to the
flavor's ID and having a potentially misleading 404 Not Found error.

Since this temporarily involves two separate proxy delete APIs, I've
called the test verify_delete2. When we apply it everywhere in a mass
change, we will go back to one test.

Change-Id: I755c57e9bd9cec597a5bcf84c527e7bd6d710fb3
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-03-18 04:07:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/d785466bb2326465fb3916344900e193bd8ec062', 'message': "Proxy delete method

This change introduces a common delete API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around deleting a resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to deleting a server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls delete on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. Additionally, a decorator has been added that
checks if resources that are passed to it are of the appropriate type
for that operation. For example, this will raise ValueError if you try
to call delete_server with a flavor, rather than making the call to the
flavor's ID and having a potentially misleading 404 Not Found error.

Two things to note: Since this temporarily involves two separate proxy
delete APIs, I've called the test verify_delete2. That calls a second
implementation of the verify function as _verify2 -- I would strongly
prefer to leave that as-is for now instead of adding in temporary logic
to complicate that method (all it does is remove the self.session from
assert_called_with).  When we apply this API everywhere in a mass
change, we will go back to one test. When all of the APIs have been
changed, we will go back to one verify.

Change-Id: I755c57e9bd9cec597a5bcf84c527e7bd6d710fb3

This change introduces a common delete API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around deleting a resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to deleting a server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls delete on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. Additionally, a decorator has been added that
checks if resources that are passed to it are of the appropriate type
for that operation. For example, this will raise ValueError if you try
to call delete_server with a flavor, rather than making the call to the
flavor's ID and having a potentially misleading 404 Not Found error. In
the case of a 404, by default this is ignored, but if ignore_missing is
set to False, we handle a 404 and raise exceptions.ResourceNotFound as a
more descriptive exception.

implementation of the verify function as _verify2 -- I would strongly
prefer to leave that as-is for now instead of adding in temporary logic

"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-03-24 15:27:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/80cc05577f9ed915ce391dcc3eebab6dda627028', 'message': "Proxy delete method

This change introduces a common delete API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around deleting a resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to deleting a server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls delete on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. This value is checked before making the request
to see if we can determine it's of the wrong resource type by the
_check_resource decorator.

Additionally, in the case of a 404, by default this is ignored, but if
ignore_missing is set to False, we handle a 404 and raise
exceptions.ResourceNotFound as a more descriptive exception.

Change-Id: I755c57e9bd9cec597a5bcf84c527e7bd6d710fb3
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-03-26 19:23:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/e8d2a4a82e51e81bc3ef4562f9b25be351911dc8', 'message': "Proxy delete method

This change introduces a common delete API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around deleting a resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to deleting a server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls delete on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. This value is checked before making the request
to see if we can determine it's of the wrong resource type by the
_check_resource decorator.

Additionally, in the case of a 404, by default this is ignored, but if
ignore_missing is set to False, we handle a 404 and raise

commit_message:
Proxy delete method

This change introduces a common delete API that can be applied to every
proxy method that revolves around deleting a resource. In particular,
the change applies that base method to deleting a server.

The method takes either a resource or an ID and calls delete on the
corresponding resource, after obtaining the canonical ID for that value
out of Resource.get_id. This value is checked before making the request
to see if we can determine it's of the wrong resource type by the
_check_resource decorator.

Additionally, in the case of a 404, by default this is ignored, but if
ignore_missing is set to False, we handle a 404 and raise
exceptions.ResourceNotFound as a more descriptive exception.

Change-Id: I755c57e9bd9cec597a5bcf84c527e7bd6d710fb3

commit_message:
Add a suspension engine section

To make it more clear as to what the suspend() method
does add a special case section in the engine docs that
describes exactly (at a somewhat high-level) what it is
doing (and how it does it).

Change-Id: If2fbba744e460e99d4bb7da58809a27ca7dd37d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/48/169548/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: new round of :ref:`scheduling <scheduling>` occurs and this process repeats all currently executing work will be allowed to finish (see :ref:`suspension <suspension>`).Special cases ============= .. _suspension: Suspension ---------- Each engine implements a :py:func:`~taskflow.engines.base.Engine.suspend` method that can be used to externally (or internally) request that the engine stop :ref:`scheduling <scheduling>` new work. By default what this performs is a transition of the flow state from ``RUNNING`` into a ``SUSPENDING`` state (which will later transition into a ``SUSPENDED`` state). Since an engine may be remotely executing atoms (or locally executing them) and there is currently no preemption what occurs is that the engines :py:class:`~taskflow.engines.action_engine.runner.Runner` state machine will detect this transition into ``SUSPENDING`` has occurred and the state machine will avoid scheduling new work (it will though let active work continue). After the current work has finished the engine will transition from ``SUSPENDING`` into ``SUSPENDED`` and return from its :py:func:`~taskflow.engines.base.Engine.run` method. At that point the there *may* be unfinished work in the flow that was not finished (but which can be resumed at a later point in time).
deleted_lines: new round of :ref:`scheduling <scheduling>` occurs and this process repeats all currently executing atoms will be allowed to finish (and there results will be saved).

added_lines: def test_delete_data(self): obj = self.MyObject() run = agnostic.Runtime() run.create_policy('test') run.register_trigger('p', lambda old, new: obj.increment()) run.insert('p(x) :- q(x, y), equal(y, 1)') run.insert('q(1, 1)') self.assertEqual(obj.value, 1) run.delete('q(1, 1)') self.assertEqual(obj.value, 2) def test_multi_policies(self): obj = self.MyObject() run = agnostic.Runtime() run.debug_mode() run.create_policy('alice') run.create_policy('bob') run.register_trigger('p', lambda old, new: obj.increment(), 'alice') run.insert('p(x) :- bob:q(x)', target='alice') run.insert('q(1)', target='bob') self.assertEqual(obj.value, 1) run.delete('q(1)', target='bob') self.assertEqual(obj.value, 2) def test_multi_policies2(self): obj = self.MyObject() run = agnostic.Runtime() run.debug_mode() run.create_policy('classification') run.create_policy('keystone') run.register_trigger('no_email', lambda old, new: obj.increment(), 'classification') run.insert('no_email(username, email):-keystone:users(username, name, enabled, tenantId, id, email),equal(email, "None")', target='classification') run.insert('users(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, "None")', target='keystone') self.assertEqual(obj.value, 1) run.delete('users(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, "None")', target='keystone') self.assertEqual(obj.value, 2)

commit_message:
Fix inconsistent rule insert bug

Previously, if you inserted 2 facts into the policy engine with
different numbers of columns, you would get an error that would
leave the system in an inconsistent state where the 2nd fact
is in the policy engine, but is not indexed, and is not in
the database.

This fix catches exceptions thrown during indexing and reverts
the change to the policy-engine before re-raising the exception.
This fix also includes a test for this flaw.

Related-bug: 1438398
Change-Id: Id2abf06da68cf87cee7a8754564e143fe10db807

commit_message:
Add native support for Datalog column references

Previously we supported column references within the Datalog
policy language by transforming them at compile-time into
traditional Datalog rules.  This is problematic because
it requires the schema be known at the time the rules are
inserted into the system, and now that datasources can be
created/deleted at runtime we no longer know the schemas
when the rules are inserted.

This builds column-references into the compiler, the
analysis algorithms, and the evaluation procedures so
that everything works natively with both traditional
positional arguments and column-reference arguments.

Change-Id: I28c1d9efd9086a2e559cab50e4b4cc63428cbdda

subject: Add _check_resource to BaseProxy
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-24 15:23:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/14e9d4ab4ecaf424441b904ca38c2fca130071fb', 'message': 'Add _check_resource to BaseProxy

All of the base methods on BaseProxy need to check their arguments in
order to prevent requests from being made on the wrong types, preventing
potentially confusing error messages. This was originally part of the
delete change but is better by itself.

Change-Id: I75d398fda55e80db5877bb7d55f7ff3d5dbd88ad
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-26 19:15:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/6ef99d29e5facc05491908ac74c93477ff67a1d3', 'message': "Add _check_resource to BaseProxy

All of the base methods on BaseProxy need to check their arguments in
order to prevent requests from being made on the wrong types, preventing
potentially confusing error messages.

This decorator covers two angles:

1. When strict=False, the `actual` parameter is checked to see if it's
   the `expected` type IFF `actual` is an instance of Resource. When
   the type does not match, ValueError is raised. If the type is
   something else, such as an id, it is passed on to the underlying
   method when it is able to additionally operate on an id, such as on a
   get or delete call.
2. When strict=True, the `actual` parameter *must* be an instance of
   Resource, otherwise it raises ValueError. This is necessary for
   methods such as create which can't operate solely on an id but
   require additional information.

As the majority of operations can be carried out with just an ID, False
is the default strict mode.

Change-Id: I75d398fda55e80db5877bb7d55f7ff3d5dbd88ad
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-03-26 21:21:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/f9bf6a21d099e624d3e48f35b9fbcc2a5b79d9e3', 'message': "Add _check_resource to BaseProxy

All of the base methods on BaseProxy need to check their arguments in
order to prevent requests from being made on the wrong types, preventing
potentially confusing error messages.

This decorator covers two cases:

1. When strict=False, the `actual` parameter is checked to see if it's
   the `expected` type IFF `actual` is an instance of Resource. When
   the type does not match, ValueError is raised. If the type is
   something else, such as an id, it is passed on to the underlying
   method when it is able to additionally operate on an id, such as on a
   get or delete call.
2. When strict=True, the `actual` parameter *must* be an instance of
   Resource, otherwise it raises ValueError. This is necessary for
   methods such as create which can't operate solely on an id but
   require additional information.

As the majority of operations can be carried out with just an ID, False
is the default strict mode.

Change-Id: I75d398fda55e80db5877bb7d55f7ff3d5dbd88ad

commit_message:
Add _check_resource to BaseProxy

All of the base methods on BaseProxy need to check their arguments in
order to prevent requests from being made on the wrong types, preventing
potentially confusing error messages.

This decorator covers two cases:

1. When strict=False, the `actual` parameter is checked to see if it's
   the `expected` type IFF `actual` is an instance of Resource. When
   the type does not match, ValueError is raised. If the type is
   something else, such as an id, it is passed on to the underlying
   method when it is able to additionally operate on an id, such as on a
   get or delete call.
2. When strict=True, the `actual` parameter must be an instance of
   Resource or None, otherwise it raises ValueError. This is necessary for
   methods such as create which can't operate solely on an id but
   require additional information.

In shorter terms: 1) if it's a resource we check it, 2) it has to be
a resource or nothing.

As the majority of operations can be carried out with just an ID, False
is the default strict mode.

Change-Id: I75d398fda55e80db5877bb7d55f7ff3d5dbd88ad

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import testtools from openstack import proxy from openstack import resource class Test_check_resource(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(Test_check_resource, self).setUp() def method(self, expected_type, value): return value self.sot = mock.Mock() self.sot.method = method def _test_correct(self, value): decorated = proxy._check_resource(self.sot.method) rv = decorated(self.sot, resource.Resource, value) self.assertEqual(value, rv) def test_correct_resource(self): res = resource.Resource() self._test_correct(res) def test_id(self): self._test_correct("abc123-id") def test_incorrect_resource(self): class OneType(resource.Resource): pass class AnotherType(resource.Resource): pass value = AnotherType() decorated = proxy._check_resource(self.sot.method) self.assertRaisesRegexp(ValueError, "Expected OneType but received AnotherType", decorated, self.sot, OneType, value)

commit_message:
Simplify environment.d scripts

Just leave the exports there, removing the shebang as they are sourced
and not executed directly.

This has also the side-effect of making dib-lint ignore them, and thus
enforce on them checks which don't make any good in them.

Change-Id: I2a9506634a9b636ca97bd4a1fab72307c95b5388
Partial-Bug: #1435306

distribution.

commit_message:
Improve error handling when JSON is not returned by agent

Sometimes the agent is not returning valid JSON in the response.  Handle
it better and record information about the request and the response to
help with debugging.

Will now raise an exception similar to this:
ironic.common.exception.IronicException: Unable to decode response as JSON.
Request URL: http://127.0.0.1:9999/v1/commands
Request body: "{"name": "standby.run_image",
                "params": {"image_info": {"image_id": "test_image"}}}"
Response: "this is not json"

Change-Id: I483884ca5727fbaa3120e2f7c2b381a7d7e8be17
Closes-Bug: 1439498
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/75/170275/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
try: result = response.json() except ValueError: raise exception.IronicException( _('Unable to decode response as JSON.
' 'Request URL: %(url)s
Request body: "%(body)s"
' 'Response: "%(response)s"' ) % ({'response': response.text, 'body': body, 'url': url})) return result

commit_message:
IPv6 SLAAC subnet create should update ports on net

If ports are first created on a network, and then an IPv6 SLAAC
or DHCPv6-stateless subnet is created on that network, then the
ports created prior to the subnet create are not getting
automatically updated (associated) with addresses for the
SLAAC/DHCPv6-stateless subnet, as required.

Change-Id: I5901db6655c045c0e78c7cb7fc51ce8c9a9e1933
Closes-Bug: 1427474

commit_message:
Use the new ':expect' syntax in rspec 3.x

- The old ':should' syntax in rspec 3.x is deprecated
  in favor of ':expect' syntax.

Change-Id: Iddc0805d4a5339fd43649e361a1bb3c84478fa1c
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Do sleep(0) for first task sleep

This results in a functional test run which is up to 20% faster than
the current sleep(1)

Closes-Bug: #1439216

commit_message:
Add inc/rootwrap

Rootwrap shouldn't be a unique snowflake.  Plus the binaries tend
to be called assuming PATH will find them.  Not so with venvs
so we need to work around that brokenness.

Configure Cinder and Nova to use configure_rootwrap().

Change-Id: I8ee1f66014875caf20a2d14ff6ef3672673ba85a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/73/168773/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # # **inc/rootwrap** - Rootwrap functions # # Handle rootwrap's foibles # Uses: ``STACK_USER`` # Defines: ``SUDO_SECURE_PATH_FILE`` # Save trace setting INC_ROOT_TRACE=$(set +o | grep xtrace) set +o xtrace # Accumulate all additions to sudo's ``secure_path`` in one file read last # so they all work in a venv configuration SUDO_SECURE_PATH_FILE=${SUDO_SECURE_PATH_FILE:-/etc/sudoers.d/zz-secure-path} # Add a directory to the common sudo ``secure_path`` # add_sudo_secure_path dir function add_sudo_secure_path { local dir=$1 local line # This is pretty simplistic for now - assume only the first line is used if [[ -r SUDO_SECURE_PATH_FILE ]]; then line=$(head -1 $SUDO_SECURE_PATH_FILE) else line="Defaults:$STACK_USER secure_path=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/bin" fi # Only add ``dir`` if it is not already present if [[ $line =~ $dir ]]; then echo "${line}:$dir" | sudo tee $SUDO_SECURE_PATH_FILE sudo chmod 400 $SUDO_SECURE_PATH_FILE sudo chown root:root $SUDO_SECURE_PATH_FILE fi } # Configure rootwrap # Make a load of assumptions otherwise we'll have 6 arguments # configure_rootwrap project bin conf-src-dir function configure_rootwrap { local project=$1 # xx local rootwrap_bin=$2 # /opt/stack/xx.venv/bin/xx-rootwrap local rootwrap_conf_src_dir=$3 # /opt/stack/xx/etc/xx # Start fresh with rootwrap filters sudo rm -rf /etc/${project}/rootwrap.d sudo install -d -o root -g root -m 755 /etc/${project}/rootwrap.d sudo install -o root -g root -m 644 $rootwrap_conf_src_dir/rootwrap.d/*.filters /etc/${project}/rootwrap.d # Set up rootwrap.conf, pointing to /etc/*/rootwrap.d sudo install -o root -g root -m 644 $rootwrap_conf_src_dir/rootwrap.conf /etc/${project}/rootwrap.conf sudo sed -e "s:^filters_path=.*$:filters_path=/etc/${project}/rootwrap.d:" -i /etc/${project}/rootwrap.conf # Specify rootwrap.conf as first parameter to rootwrap rootwrap_sudo_cmd="$rootwrap_bin /etc/${project}/rootwrap.conf *" # Set up the rootwrap sudoers local tempfile=$(mktemp) echo "$STACK_USER ALL=(root) NOPASSWD: $rootwrap_sudo_cmd" >$tempfile chmod 0440 $tempfile sudo chown root:root $tempfile sudo mv $tempfile /etc/sudoers.d/${project}-rootwrap # Add bin dir to sudo's secure_path because rootwrap is being called # without a path because BROKEN. add_sudo_secure_path $(dirname $rootwrap_bin) } # Restore xtrace $INC_ROOT_TRACE # Local variables: # mode: shell-script # End:

commit_message:
Add basic Makefile

There are a couple of targets in here that some might find useful in
doing DevStack testing in multiple remote VMs.

There are some of the usual boring targets too, like stack and unstack,
that do exactly what you would expect.

Change-Id: I7974cac4cc527bacf6f183ac1f344428b05f2fdc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/03/169403/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # DevStack Makefile of Sanity # Interesting targets: # ds-remote - Create a Git remote for use by ds-push and ds-pull targets # DS_REMOTE_URL must be set on the command line # # ds-push - Merge a list of branches taken from .ds-test and push them # to the ds-remote repo in ds-test branch # # ds-pull - Pull the remote ds-test branch into a fresh local branch # # refresh - Performs a sequence of unstack, refresh and stack # Duplicated from stackrc for now DEST=/opt/stack WHEELHOUSE=$(DEST)/.wheelhouse all: echo "This just saved you from a terrible mistake!" # Do Some Work stack: ./stack.sh unstack: ./unstack.sh wheels: WHEELHOUSE=$(WHEELHOUSE) tools/build-wheels.sh docs: tox -edocs # Just run the shocco source formatting build docs-build: INSTALL_SHOCCO=True tools/build_docs.sh # Just run the Sphinx docs build docs-rst: python setup.py build_sphinx # Run the bashate test bashate: tox -ebashate # Run the function tests test: tests/test_ini_config.sh tests/test_meta_config.sh tests/test_ip.sh tests/test_refs.sh # Spiff up the place a bit clean: ./clean.sh rm -rf accrc doc/build test*-e *.egg-info # Clean out the cache too realclean: clean rm -rf files/cirros*.tar.gz files/Fedora*.qcow2 $(WHEELHOUSE) # Repo stuffs pull: git pull # These repo targets are used to maintain a branch in a remote repo that # consists of one or more local branches merged and pushed to the remote. # This is most useful for iterative testing on multiple or remote servers # while keeping the working repo local. # # It requires: # * a remote pointing to a remote repo, often GitHub is used for this # * a branch name to be used on the remote # * a local file containing the list of local branches to be merged into # the remote branch GIT_REMOTE_NAME=ds-test GIT_REMOTE_BRANCH=ds-test # Push the current branch to a remote named ds-test ds-push: git checkout master git branch -D $(GIT_REMOTE_BRANCH) || true git checkout -b $(GIT_REMOTE_BRANCH) for i in $(shell cat .$(GIT_REMOTE_BRANCH) | grep -v "^#" | grep "[^ ]"); do \ git merge --no-edit $$i; \ done git push -f $(GIT_REMOTE_NAME) HEAD:$(GIT_REMOTE_BRANCH) # Pull the ds-test branch ds-pull: git checkout master git branch -D $(GIT_REMOTE_BRANCH) || true git pull $(GIT_REMOTE_NAME) $(GIT_REMOTE_BRANCH) git checkout $(GIT_REMOTE_BRANCH) # Add the remote - set DS_REMOTE_URL=htps://example.com/ on the command line ds-remote: git remote add $(GIT_REMOTE_NAME) $(DS_REMOTE_URL) # Refresh the current DevStack checkout nd re-initialize refresh: unstack ds-pull stack

commit_message:
Adds "solum info" command for connection info

Returns Solum client version, and some information
about the API endpoint, including the auth and API endpoints,
the user name and tenant/project, and the current version of
the Solum API.

Change-Id: Iabd3e126ce42c48c1024b4c098ecf72eb8e753aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-solumclient refs/changes/31/170231/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class NoSubCommands(CommandsBase): """Command parsing class that lacks an 'action'.""" parser = None solum = None json_output = False def __init__(self, parser): self.parser = parser self._get_global_flags() try: self._get_auth_flags() except exc.CommandError as ce: print(self.__doc__) print("ERROR: %s" % ce.message) return parsed, _ = self.parser.parse_known_args() client_args = vars(parsed) if 'os_auth_token' in client_args: del client_args['os_auth_token'] self.client = solum_client.get_client(parsed.solum_api_version, **client_args) return self.info() def info(self): pass

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-30 06:41:27.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/index.rst', 'doc/source/configuration.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/5f2eb6dade5f3b19b8905b97d8e4018b5e068321', 'message': "Add a target for, and link to, minimal config docs

Reading through the docs for the first time, the reader encounters an
instruction to provide a minimal configuration, with a link that they'd
expect to tell them how to do this.

At present the link actually takes them to the top of
configuration.html, where they read some history about how devstack's
configuration has changed over time.

This is interesting and important and should be in the docs - but in my
opinion a link about setting up a minimal configuration would be more
useful if it takes me to a place that tells them about a minimal
configuration.

To get this, I've had to an an explicit link target into
configuration.rst. I'm not hugely keen on this approach, as I don't
think it scales well. I'd be open to suggestions about other
approaches. The only idea I've had so far though is to simply move the
minimal configuration section right to the top of the page, so that a
link to the doc is a link to the minimal config - the historical
information could be moved to its own topic somewhere further down the doc.

Change-Id: I231ca1b7f17b55f09a4e058dab8ee433893f737e
"}]
commit_message:
Add a target for, and link to, minimal config docs

Reading through the docs for the first time, the reader encounters an
instruction to provide a minimal configuration, with a link that they'd
expect to tell them how to do this.

At present the link actually takes them to the top of
configuration.html, where they read some history about how devstack's
configuration has changed over time.

This is interesting and important and should be in the docs - but in my
opinion a link about setting up a minimal configuration would be more
useful if it takes me to a place that tells them about a minimal
configuration.

To get this, I've had to an an explicit link target into
configuration.rst. I'm not hugely keen on this approach, as I don't
think it scales well. I'd be open to suggestions about other
approaches. The only idea I've had so far though is to simply move the
minimal configuration section right to the top of the page, so that a
link to the doc is a link to the minimal config - the historical
information could be moved to its own topic somewhere further down the doc.

Change-Id: I231ca1b7f17b55f09a4e058dab8ee433893f737e

commit_message:
If cells enabled create a fixed network in the API cell

Now that tempest is querying for a network before making server create
calls the fixed network needs to be known by the API cell.  Server
creates should work for networks defined in both databases, but defining
a new network via the API will continue to not work.

Change-Id: I32461add0d20940a55385c8b34cd493e2561615e

commit_message:
Fixes ovs-vsctl add port issue

Setup of OVS may fail, if ports that are added,
are already exist. Add "--may-exist" directive to OVS
add-port command to prevent this behaviour.

Change-Id: I2280be9a63a4a6fbc747b5e32b602697b555ffa8
Closes-Bug: #1394162

commit_message:
Add roles when we create groups

We should prime the groups that were created with some roles on
projects. Eventually we can add users directly to the groups
and not have to resort to individual user assignments.

"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-04-02 16:30:08.000000000', 'files': ['lib/tempest'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/d2cb234be4b5e6d70635fc7578d951a42a41cc4a', 'message': "Set qcow image file location with right cirros version

because tempest falls back to using uec images (which devstack was

Change-Id: I05af346b3c9be9560dc8846dd1f437cfbb2d5005

commit_message:
Set qcow image file location with right cirros version

This commit ensures we also set the qcow image location in the
tempest config when we update qcow version. The tempest config has
a default value for img_file (which is incorrect) but before we can
remove the defaults in tempest we need to ensure devstack is using
it properly first. The only reason the tests weren't failing here is
because tempest falls back to using uec images (which devstack was
correctly setting config for) if qcow isn't found. The img_dir was
also hardcoded assuming a uec image, however if qcow is intended to be
used you'll need to be able to override that, which is added as
part of this commit.

Change-Id: I05af346b3c9be9560dc8846dd1f437cfbb2d5005
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/61/170161/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG scenario img_file "cirros-${CIRROS_VERSION}-${CIRROS_ARCH}-disk.img"

commit_message:
Swift PyEClib build requires 'make'

PyEClib was introduced recently to swift-master. It tries
to build liberasurecode which requires the `make` binary.

Change-Id: I8acfed4f7b46a29eac36f6acbe1d66e7fff800db

commit_message:
Rename the README.md files into README.rst

Rename them to README.rst as diskimage-builder supports only .rst files,
and it might seem [1] that .md files might be considered a new dib-lint
error.

While the current README.rst might not be fully rst-compliant, there is
no documentation generated for sahara-image-elements, so this does not
cause regressions.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/169992/

Change-Id: Ide764b653eb8939818e13df2778448bbe4f8f3b5

commit_message:
Use host's NTPD as the time source for NTPD on the master node

To get NTPD on master node syncronized more quickly but not abuse
external NTPD servers, let's try to use NTPD on the host where test
is running.

When master node provisioned, NTPD on the host is checked via
'ntpdate' command. If it completes successfuly, then replase
settings for NTP* servers in the /etc/fuel/astute.yaml

Change-Id: Ida6c12013bcd95a638ffc624532ea71e1716b64d
Related-Bug: #1433484

commit_message:
Fix swiftclient tests

We were not properly faking out swiftclient which lead to swift tests
passing without ever running through the swift generator code. Properly
monkey patch swiftclient so that we can test this code.

Change-Id: Ie7701cebb4c4e8ffc1289421df9c136c7de3f008
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-loganalyze refs/changes/26/170326/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import fixtures import swiftclient # noqa needed for monkeypatching class fake_swiftclient(object): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): pass def get_object(self, container, name, resp_chunk_size=None): name = name[len('non-existent'):] if resp_chunk_size: def _object_body(): with open(base.samples_path('samples') + name) as f: while buf: yield buf buf = f.read(resp_chunk_size) object_body = _object_body() else: with open(base.samples_path('samples') + name) as f: object_body = f.read() return [], object_body self.useFixture(fixtures.MonkeyPatch( 'swiftclient.client.Connection', fake_swiftclient))
deleted_lines: import swiftclient def fake_get_object(self, container, name, resp_chunk_size=None): if resp_chunk_size: def _object_body(): with open(base.samples_path('samples') + name) as f: buf = f.read(resp_chunk_size) while buf: yield buf object_body = _object_body() else: with open(base.samples_path('samples') + name) as f: object_body = f.read() return [], object_body swiftclient.client.Connection.get_object = fake_get_object

commit_message:
Commits changes available on PyPi

The release .2 on PyPi already includes changes acted uppon in
Horizon. This patch commits those changes to stackforge. It
also adds a .gitreview file.

Change-Id: Ibc25f66dba97c2121b5d7fe485175d7cd76b6267

commit_message:
RMC NIC on each VM

RMC allows the management entity to provide directives to the virtual
machine, for things such as dynamically modifying resource allocations
(memory, CPU and I/O) as well as migration.  RMC runs over Ethernet.

This change set provides an additional NIC that will be deployed with
the VMs to provide the communication path for RMC.

Change-Id: I71aa328b021f0a19e27e5a7611df94896957e351
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/60/169760/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Atributes for secure RMC SECURE_RMC_VSWITCH = 'MGMT' SECURE_RMC_VLAN = 4094 def crt_secure_rmc_vif(adapter, instance, host_uuid): """Creates the Secure RMC Network Adapter on the VM. :param adapter: The pypowervm adapter API interface. :param instance: The nova instance to create the VIF against. :param host_uuid: The host system UUID. """ lpar_uuid = get_pvm_uuid(instance) cna.crt_cna(adapter, host_uuid, lpar_uuid, SECURE_RMC_VLAN, vswitch=SECURE_RMC_VSWITCH, crt_vswitch=True) def get_secure_rmc_vswitch(adapter, host_uuid): """Returns the vSwitch that is used for secure RMC. :param adapter: The pypowervm adapter API interface. :param host_uuid: The host system UUID. """ resp = adapter.read(pvm_ms.System.schema_type, root_id=host_uuid, child_type=pvm_net.VSwitch.schema_type) vswitches = pvm_net.VSwitch.wrap(resp) for vswitch in vswitches: if vswitch.name == SECURE_RMC_VSWITCH: return vswitch # Must not have found it. Therefore we should create it vswitch = pvm_net.VSwitch.bld(SECURE_RMC_VSWITCH) crt_resp = adapter.create(vswitch, pvm_ms.System.schema_type, root_id=host_uuid, child_type=pvm_net.VSwitch.schema_type) return pvm_net.VSwitch.wrap(crt_resp)

commit_message:
Enhance VIOS logic to localdisk flow

Currently the VIOS logic in the localdisk would simply look for the
first Virtual I/O Server.

This enhancement enables the system to look through all of the VIOSes on
the system when determining the volume group to use.

An optional parameter was added to enable the user to specify exactly
which VIOS.  However, this is not required and is only needed if
multiple Virtual I/O Servers have a volume group of the same name.

Change-Id: I275384078507b85c1be884e05c08336e6cd5f534
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/34/170134/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from pypowervm.wrappers import managed_system as pvm_ms help='Volume Group to use for block device operations. Must ' 'not be rootvg.'), cfg.StrOpt('volume_group_vios_name', default='', help='(Optional) The name of the Virtual I/O Server hosting ' 'the volume group. If not specified, the system will ' 'query through the Virtual I/O Servers looking for ' 'one that matches the name. This is only needed if the ' 'system has multiple Virtual I/O Servers with a volume ' 'group whose name is duplicated.') # Query to get the Volume Group UUID self.vios_uuid, self.vg_uuid = self._get_vg_uuid(self.vg_name) def _get_vg_uuid(self, name): """Returns the VIOS and VG UUIDs for the volume group. Will iterate over the VIOSes to find the VG with the name. :param name: The name of the volume group. :return vios_uuid: The Virtual I/O Server pypowervm UUID. :return vg_uuid: The Volume Group pypowervm UUID. """ vios_resp = self.adapter.read(pvm_ms.System.schema_type, root_id=self.host_uuid, child_type=pvm_vios.VIOS.schema_type) vios_wraps = pvm_vios.VIOS.wrap(vios_resp) # Loop through each vios to find the one with the appropriate name. for vios_wrap in vios_wraps: # If the VIOS was specified and the name does not match, then # skip this VIOS. if (CONF.volume_group_vios_name and CONF.volume_group_vios_name != vios_wrap.name): continue # Search the feed for the volume group resp = self.adapter.read(pvm_vios.VIOS.schema_type, root_id=vios_wrap.uuid, child_type=pvm_stg.VG.schema_type) vol_grps = pvm_stg.VG.wrap(resp) for vol_grp in vol_grps: LOG.info(_LI('Volume group: %s') % vol_grp.name) if name == vol_grp.name: return vios_wrap.uuid, vol_grp.uuid
deleted_lines: from nova_powervm.virt.powervm import vios help='Volume Group to use for block device operations.') # TODO(IBM) Query the VIOSes to find the one containing the VG. # This is a temporary method to find the VIOS. vios_map = vios.get_vios_name_map(self.adapter, self.host_uuid) self.vios_name, self.vios_uuid = vios_map.items()[0] self.vg_uuid = self._get_vg_uuid(self.adapter, self.vios_uuid, CONF.volume_group_name) @staticmethod def _get_vg_uuid(adapter, vios_uuid, name): try: resp = adapter.read(pvm_vios.VIOS.schema_type, root_id=vios_uuid, child_type=pvm_stg.VG.schema_type) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) raise e # Search the feed for the volume group vol_grps = pvm_stg.VG.wrap(resp) for vol_grp in vol_grps: LOG.info(_LI('Volume group: %s') % vol_grp.name) if name == vol_grp.name: return vol_grp.uuid

subject: Modify keystone content for Kilo
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-25 16:48:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/cb6688e6abcb244b3e725c8bb270609f713ca411', 'message': 'Modify keystone content for Kilo

Modify keystone content for Kilo as follows:

1) Replace default eventlet front-end with Apache front-end
   to provide a more production-style deployment.

   * Disable keystone service from starting up automatically
     because it creates port conflicts with Apache.
   * Use the Apache virtual host configuration template from
     the keystone source repository.
   * Use the WSGI components from the keystone source
     repository because the packages don't include them.

2) Replace SQL back-end with Memcache back-end for tokens to
   provide a more production-style deployment.

   * Remove cron job that deletes expired tokens from the SQL
     database.

3) Enable version 3 API.

   * Change "tenant" to "project" to align with v3 API
     terminology.
   * Include tests to verify operation.

4) Replace python-keystoneclient with python-openstackclient.

   * Update openrc files to work with python-openstackclient.

5) Replace password entry on CLI with prompts.

6) Move service and endpoint creation section before user and
   project creation section to improve flow.

Many of these changes stem from keystone deprecations and
recommendations from the keystone PTL. Also, this patch only
addresses Ubuntu. For other distributions, please submit
additional patches rather than modifying this patch.

Implements: blueprint installguide-kilo
Change-Id: I9a2e53f14d6ed41df0085256c20904760a58ea25
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-25 18:06:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/6978b3b8f7c7f441a36b5dad4148542948aaa529', 'message': 'Modify keystone content for Kilo

commit_message:
Modify keystone content for Kilo

Modify keystone content for Kilo as follows:

1) Replace default eventlet front-end with Apache front-end
   to provide a more production-style deployment.

   * Disable keystone service from starting up automatically
     because it creates port conflicts with Apache.
   * Use the Apache virtual host configuration template from
     the keystone source repository.
   * Use the WSGI components from the keystone source
     repository because the packages don't include them.
   * Will update source repository links after release.

2) Replace SQL back-end with Memcache back-end for tokens to
   provide a more production-style deployment.

   * Remove cron job that deletes expired tokens from the SQL
     database.

3) Enable version 3 API.

   * Change "tenant" to "project" to align with v3 API
     terminology.
   * Include tests to verify operation.

4) Replace python-keystoneclient with python-openstackclient.

   * Update openrc files to work with python-openstackclient.

5) Replace password entry on CLI with prompts.

6) Move service and endpoint creation section before user and
   project creation section to improve flow.

7) Add note about adding sections and options to default
   configuration files.

8) Disable temporary authentication token mechanism prior to
   service verification.

Many of these changes stem from keystone deprecations and
recommendations from the keystone PTL. Also, this patch only
addresses Ubuntu. For other distributions, please submit
additional patches rather than modifying this patch.

Implements: blueprint installguide-kilo
Change-Id: I9a2e53f14d6ed41df0085256c20904760a58ea25

commit_message:
Add index for port

This patch will speed up SELECTs Port with filters by
'network_id + device_owner' and 'network_id + mac_address'.

Closes-bug: #1421089

Change-Id: Ied90b6304df971a6049871f65df3e1aaee624647

commit_message:
Skip test_volume_boot_pattern until bug 1439806 is fixed

This test creates a bootable volume, uses it to create an instance
after which it snapshots the volume.

As a last step, the created instances are stopped. During cleanup,
the volume snapshot will be deleted while the volume is still
attached.

Nova assisted volume snapshot deletion will fail as this requires
the instance to be running.

Change-Id: I26e5837b9d5b39b8394ec2f98c280743d4c9c699
Related-Bug: #1439806

commit_message:
Rename cache bust argument to __CACHE_BUST__

Since migration to Gulp, commit SHA is not used to bust cache.
Instead we use current date. So we need to rename argument name
accordingly to avoid confusion.

Change-Id: I33b31d69231fefff9f455d2dbbeca0230ca8dccc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/11/170511/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .pipe(replace('__CACHE_BUST__', Date.now()))

commit_message:
Add API tests for subnet-create with subnetpool

With subnetpool, we can create subnet with subnetpool.
User can specify CIDR or prefixlen for subnet allocation.
If neither is specified, CIDR will be chosen from the
pool using the default-prefixlen of the pool.

Change-Id: Ifb1d51b041777554e974dc375312bf360c367d88
Depends-on: I59a221f4f434718fb77bd132dbbe1ff50fce4b0c
Partially-Implements: blueprint subnet-allocation
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/71/168371/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _create_subnet_from_pool(self, subnet_values=None, pool_values=None): pool_name, pool_id = self._create_subnetpool(self.client, pool_values) subnet_name = data_utils.rand_name(SUBNETPOOL_NAME) network = self.create_network() network_id = network['id'] subnet_data = {'subnet': {'name': subnet_name, 'network_id': network_id, "ip_version": self.ip_version, "subnetpool_id": pool_id}} if subnet_values: for k, v in subnet_values.iteritems(): subnet_data['subnet'][k] = v body = self.client.create_subnet(subnet_data) self.addCleanup(self.client.delete_subnetpool, pool_id) self.addCleanup(self.client.delete_network, network_id) subnet = body['subnet'] return pool_id, subnet @test.attr(type='smoke') @test.idempotent_id('1362ed7d-3089-42eb-b3a5-d6cb8398ee77') def test_create_subnet_from_pool_with_prefixlen(self): subnet_values = {"prefixlen": self.max_prefixlen} pool_id, subnet = self._create_subnet_from_pool(subnet_values) cidr = str(subnet['cidr']) self.assertEqual(pool_id, subnet['subnetpool_id']) self.assertTrue(cidr.endswith(str(self.max_prefixlen))) @test.attr(type='smoke') @test.idempotent_id('86b86189-9789-4582-9c3b-7e2bfe5735ee') def test_create_subnet_from_pool_with_subnet_cidr(self): subnet_values = {"cidr": self.subnet_cidr} pool_id, subnet = self._create_subnet_from_pool(subnet_values) cidr = str(subnet['cidr']) self.assertEqual(pool_id, subnet['subnetpool_id']) self.assertEqual(cidr, self.subnet_cidr) @test.attr(type='smoke') @test.idempotent_id('83f76e3a-9c40-40c2-a015-b7c5242178d8') def test_create_subnet_from_pool_with_default_prefixlen(self): # If neither cidr nor prefixlen is specified, # subnet will use subnetpool default_prefixlen for cidr. pool_id, subnet = self._create_subnet_from_pool() cidr = str(subnet['cidr']) self.assertEqual(pool_id, subnet['subnetpool_id']) prefixlen = self._subnetpool_data['subnetpool']['min_prefixlen'] self.assertTrue(cidr.endswith(str(prefixlen))) @test.attr(type='smoke') @test.idempotent_id('a64af292-ec52-4bde-b654-a6984acaf477') def test_create_subnet_from_pool_with_quota(self): pool_values = {'allocation_quota': 4} subnet_values = {"prefixlen": self.max_prefixlen} pool_id, subnet = self._create_subnet_from_pool(subnet_values, pool_values) cidr = str(subnet['cidr']) self.assertEqual(pool_id, subnet['subnetpool_id']) self.assertTrue(cidr.endswith(str(self.max_prefixlen)))

commit_message:
Add support for job-types-list

This change adds support to the client for the job-types-endpoint.
Filtering by a single value for type, plugin, and version is supported.
Config hints are not available in this interface.

Change-Id: I0240717ac74c52dd915ce1617fb5d34d87660c0b
Partial-Implements: blueprint edp-job-types-endpoint
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-saharaclient refs/changes/48/161448/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Red Hat Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from saharaclient.api import job_types as jt from saharaclient.tests.unit import base class JobTypesTest(base.BaseTestCase): body = { "name": "Hive", "plugins": [ { "description": "The Apache Vanilla plugin.", "name": "vanilla", "title": "Vanilla Apache Hadoop", "versions": { "1.2.1": {} } }, { "description": "The Hortonworks Sahara plugin.", "name": "hdp", "title": "Hortonworks Data Platform", "versions": { "1.3.2": {}, "2.0.6": {} } } ] } def test_job_types_list(self): url = self.URL + '/job-types' self.responses.get(url, json={'job_types': [self.body]}) resp = self.client.job_types.list() self.assertEqual(url, self.responses.last_request.url) self.assertIsInstance(resp[0], jt.JobType) self.assertFields(self.body, resp[0])

commit_message:
Fix use_vcenter attribute compatibility for 6.0

Add use_vcenter during in cluster attributes during
migration from 6.0 to 6.1

commit_message:
indexer: return objects rather than dict

We used to return dict from the indexer, and then convert them to
object, and then sometimes encoding them as JSON.

We know makes the indexer returns directly object that have the right
interface to be directly encoded as JSON. That reduces the number of
object we have to create down the path and improves performance.

This is only done for archive policies and metrics in this patch.

Change-Id: I518d822a25fd3c5494a554645a5bbbcfc58336fd

commit_message:
rest: allow to search for metric value

This adds a new REST API endpoint that allows to search for certain
values in a list of metric. It can be used to detect threshold or things
like that efficiently in multiple metrics at once without downloading
their measures.

Change-Id: I10cc41d87a3d54ba9a03a8bd1ed92671618053c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/64/167164/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_search_value(self): result = self.app.post_json("/v1/metric", params={"archive_policy_name": "high"}) metric = json.loads(result.text) self.app.post_json("/v1/metric/%s/measures" % metric['id'], params=[{"timestamp": '2013-01-01 12:00:00', "value": 1234.2}, {"timestamp": '2013-01-01 12:00:02', "value": 456}]) metric1 = metric['id'] result = self.app.post_json("/v1/metric", params={"archive_policy_name": "high"}) metric = json.loads(result.text) self.app.post_json("/v1/metric/%s/measures" % metric['id'], params=[{"timestamp": '2013-01-01 12:30:00', "value": 1234.2}, {"timestamp": '2013-01-01 12:00:02', "value": 456}]) metric2 = metric['id'] ret = self.app.post_json( "/v1/search/metric?metric_id=%s&metric_id=%s" "&stop=2013-01-01 12:10:00" % (metric1, metric2), params={u"∧": [{u"≥": 1000}]}, status=200) result = json.loads(ret.text) self.assertEqual( {metric1: [[u'2013-01-01T12:00:00.000000Z', 1.0, 1234.2]], metric2: []}, result)

{'plugin_name': 'vanilla', 'hadoop_version': '2.6.0'} base_scenario.template_path = 'sahara/tests/scenario/templates/vanilla/2.6.0' class TestBase(testtools.TestCase): def network(self): return username=base_scenario.credentials['os_username'], password=base_scenario.credentials['os_password'], tenant_name=base_scenario.credentials['os_tenant'], auth_url=base_scenario.credentials['os_auth_url']) def sahara(self): return clients.SaharaClient( username=base_scenario.credentials['os_username'], api_key=base_scenario.credentials['os_password'], project_name=base_scenario.credentials['os_tenant'], auth_url=base_scenario.credentials['os_auth_url'], sahara_url='http://sahara_host:8336/v1.1') def nova(self): return clients.NovaClient( auth_url=base_scenario.credentials['os_auth_url']) @mock.patch('saharaclient.client.Client', return_value=None) @mock.patch('novaclient.client.Client', return_value=None) subject: functions-libvirt: Enable DEBUG_LIBVIRT config attribute by default
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-01 10:08:58.000000000', 'files': ['lib/nova_plugins/functions-libvirt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/d3cfb82c65ae7f85b9d92e1245b1d81792a5641b', 'message': 'functions-libvirt: Enable DEBUG_LIBVIRT config attribute by default

Enabling it by default because:

  - This allows you to get the relevant logs right away when something
    in the libvirt code path fails, without having to submit another
    change and keep doing a 'recheck' to re-run the CI check/gate jobs
    until you hit the bug.

  - The libvirt log filters specified in the function
    'configure_libvirt' are much more _selective_ and not a catch-all
    debug option where you end up with the unhelpful situation of having
    to find a "specific piece of hay in a haystack"[1].

FWIW, I always have it enabled in local test environments, and I don't
see the resulting libvirtd.log growing beyond a couple of MB for
three-four days of usage.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-January/024414.html

Change-Id: I5e0b35446075b419fe473e1db8d0bfedd7009741
'}]
commit_message:
functions-libvirt: Enable DEBUG_LIBVIRT config attribute by default

Enabling it by default because:

  - This allows you to get the relevant logs right away when something
    in the libvirt code path fails, without having to submit another
    change and keep doing a 'recheck' to re-run the CI check/gate jobs
    until you hit the bug.

  - The libvirt log filters specified in the function
    'configure_libvirt' are much more _selective_ and not a catch-all
    debug option where you end up with the unhelpful situation of having
    to find a "specific piece of hay in a haystack"[1].

FWIW, I always have it enabled in local test environments, and I don't
see the resulting libvirtd.log growing beyond a couple of MB for
three-four days of usage.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-January/024414.html

Change-Id: I5e0b35446075b419fe473e1db8d0bfedd7009741
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/79/169679/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Turn on selective debug log filters for libvirt. # (NOTE: Enabling this by default, because the log filters enabled in # 'configure_libvirt' function further below are _selective_ and not # extremely verbose.) DEBUG_LIBVIRT=$(trueorfalse True DEBUG_LIBVIRT)
deleted_lines: # if we should turn on massive libvirt debugging DEBUG_LIBVIRT=$(trueorfalse False DEBUG_LIBVIRT)

commit_message:
Change default cirros ssh user

Cirros images allow connection with root and cirros by default.
Interactive sessions for root are not allowed. This will change the
default user to cirros since it allows interactive ssh sessions.

See also https://bugs.launchpad.net/cirros/+bug/1437350

Change-Id: If929ce7a3df944bd17c7f4e3042a6aea0c318b2c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/44/168344/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Don't used fixed_network.py with nova-net

If nova-net is configured there isn't any reason to specify a specific
network to use since nova-net lets you start a server with multiple
networks. This commit fixes fixed_network.py not to set a network if
nova-net is in use.

Change-Id: I7351056880817a4182cda44cba9ab6d7f3c063b3

commit_message:
Add cerberus related projects

Cerberus is a security component, facilitates integration of
third-party security programs (vulnerabilty scanners)
Sticks is a cerberus plugin dedicated to ticket management
(facilitated integration of well-known ticket managers)

Change-Id: Idcdc1b839febcbb7e0a0e883d576d6d4a42e99fe

commit_message:
Adjust regression exceptions for Nova Cells V1 job

Since several patches have merged, the set of tempest test expected
failures with cells have changed. This patch adjusts the list of
tests that should not be run in order for the job to pass.

The tests being removed from the blacklist had been failing in the
past because a flavor created by tempest could not be accessed in
child cells during instance create. Patches have since merged that
enable use of the flavor object stored in the instance object,
eliminating the need for a flavor lookup from the database. So tests
having to do only with an instance create can be removed from the list.

There are some classes of tempest tests still expected to fail in a
Cells V1 environment:

* Networks API
* Resize instance
* Floating ips
* Shelve instance
* Rescue instance

Change-Id: If32b7361521d4747dcd05db47e3bf4955ce1b232

commit_message:
Exclude the slow tag for the Nova Cells V1 job

This job is hitting the test timeout, causing it to fail. This change
adds the slow tag exclusion regex for the job.

Change-Id: I958a8ec49b08c00e3aff8c76aa293e09187719a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/21/168121/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Restore devstack centos7 to non-voting check job

This restores centos7 to a check job.  The issue with increased memory
usage is due to using using the pip version of pyOpenSSL due to
Idf3a3a914b54779172776822710b3e52e751b1d1 which blows out memory
usage; see discussion in [1].

This reverts commit 8c8d8a4d09e4568b662ace3915f89628a44450d7.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/oom-in-rax-centos7-CI-job

Change-Id: I5aa95f4a80114cc2634c14cca4eb1e0e238be320
Depends-On: Icd4100da1d5cbdb82017da046b00b9397813c2f2

commit_message:
Add check-tempest-dsvm-heat

Because heat builds on the compute base layer, it does not need to be
tested in all devstack-gate jobs. Instead create a new job that tests
heat in a devstack environment as a first step in removing it from the
standard configuration.

Specify that heat should be enabled in the devstack updown job
so that the parts that enable heat are exercised in devstack.
This is already currently the case, but this updates the job config
so that it will continue to do so later when we remove heat from
the default config.

Change-Id: I13a80cc5b669f30f55dae67fd82eb6e3f31f9dbc

commit_message:
Gnocchi: do not check requirements

As the Gnocchi project does not follow the integrated release schedule,
we are going to release on a different pace than most OpenStack
integrated projects. Having the requirements tight to the rest of the
schedule might very likely be an issue for deployer wanting to upgrade
Gnocchi while the rest of OpenStack isn't released yet.

So Gnocchi is going to follow its own dependency rules, while doing best
effort to be compatible with the rest of OpenStack obviously.

Change-Id: Id2836cf52b62ae22d39135ee725679c68fda06cf

commit_message:
Install required services for Zaqar

Zaqar's gate is current;y installing more services than it needs. This
patch sets the `ENABLED_SERVICES` var to what's really required for
zaqar to be deployed.

Change-Id: Ia7d3a2a5ed2ebb29b1a4f99c00cac4d024bcdddc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/69/169269/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export ENABLED_SERVICES=mysql,key,zaqar-server

just going to turn that off for now.

commit_message:
Switch nova-docker-f20 job to centos7

F20 nodes are having issues at the moment, and F20 is getting a bit
old anyway.  Move this to centos7 which is a better choice for
long-term testing.

Change-Id: Ifa742ba5bdae0b796b8b92336e41234fd8b7939e

[2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/router-port-forwarding

commit_message:
Make the unrecognized exception more verbose

If the gerrit config normalizer comes across an unrecognized line, add
the bad line to the exception message for debugging.

Change-Id: I60e77a0b50718fb331bad0836ca769f685e6ce93

commit_message:
Add license info to subunit2html

Subunit2html is being split out into another repo. To keep track of
copyright and license info update it with an appropriate apache header
(for the edits made on top of the original source whose license is
preserved as is).

Change-Id: I6fc16d316012fd3e1c196f74df25d725a310f6dc

commit_message:
RST: Import the HOT guide

This import requires an update to conf.py to enable the hotref
extension from os-doc-tools.

Once this guide is published, the hot-guide folder can be removed.

1) adds the user_only scope to all the files included in the toctree
in hot.rst
2) creates a separate forlder for the hot guide in the source directory
3) checks rst markuping

Change-Id: Iee6027604fb62b460ea20c7bf58b88928b1e81e1
Co-Authored-By: Gauvain Pocentek <gauvain.pocentek@objectif-libre.com>
Co-Authored-By: Olga Gusarenko <ogusarenko@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Lists for Generic Checks

The Generic check had no way to identify
a value inside a list.  Since Lists are inherantly unstable in
indexing, requiring an index to match is not practical.

Lists now follow the same approach as the OrCheck:
When specifying a value inside a list, each element
of the lsit is checked for a match.  If any of the sub lists match,
the check succeeds. Only if the entry is not in the list does the
check fail.

If the value is nested in a dictionary under the list, all of
the subordinate dictionaries are checked in a recursive manner.

Change-Id: Ia286dbd3757703779d7044b3003381eab6c5c919

added_lines: def test_single_entry_in_list_accepted(self): check = _checks.GenericCheck('a.b.c.d', 'APPLES') credentials = {'a': {'b': {'c': {'d': ['APPLES']}}}} self.assertTrue(check({}, credentials, self.enforcer)) def test_multiple_entry_in_list_accepted(self): check = _checks.GenericCheck('a.b.c.d', 'APPLES') credentials = {'a': {'b': {'c': {'d': ['Bananas', 'APPLES', 'Grapes']}}}} self.assertTrue(check({}, credentials, self.enforcer)) def test_multiple_entry_in_nested_list_accepted(self): check = _checks.GenericCheck('a.b.c.d', 'APPLES') credentials = {'a': {'b': [{'c': {'d': ['BANANAS', 'APPLES', 'GRAPES']}}, {}]}} self.assertTrue(check({}, credentials, self.enforcer)) def test_multiple_nested_lists_accepted(self): check = _checks.GenericCheck('a.b.c.d', 'APPLES') credentials = {'a': {'b': [{'a': ''}, {'c': {'d': ['BANANAS', 'APPLES', 'GRAPES']}}, {}]}} self.assertTrue(check({}, credentials, self.enforcer)) def test_entry_not_in_list_rejected(self): check = _checks.GenericCheck('a.b.c.d', 'APPLES') credentials = {'a': {'b': {'c': {'d': ['PEACHES', 'PEARS']}}}} self.assertFalse(check({}, credentials, self.enforcer))

subject: Set MySQL transaction isolation to READ_COMMITED
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-30 10:20:50.000000000', 'files': ['deployment/puppet/mysql/templates/my.cnf.erb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/4bafd9a5765fcab09438aea6400b22b39220fb2a', 'message': "Set MySQL transaction isolation to READ_COMMITED

A MySQL uses repeatable read for transactions by default.
A Postgres uses read committed by default, and an SQLite
uses serializable. Oslo.db don't set the isolation level
explicitly anywhere.

This is a problem as Openstack applications using Oslo.db
may be running under different isolation levels depending
on the backend type but the implicit isolation level
is unknown for Oslo.db code.

The solution is that Fuel should configure the MySQL
transaction_isolation=READ-COMMITTED as it looks that this
mode is implicit for backends by Oslo.db because it is a
standard for DB transations.

Change-Id: Ib4d22e1cdfb177ce236a89e7a6292292018052fa
Closes-bug: #1438107
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Set MySQL transaction isolation to READ_COMMITED

A MySQL uses repeatable read for transactions by default.
A Postgres uses read committed by default, and an SQLite
uses serializable. Oslo.db don't set the isolation level
explicitly anywhere.

This is a problem as Openstack applications using Oslo.db
may be running under different isolation levels depending
on the backend type but the implicit isolation level
is unknown for Oslo.db code.

The solution is that Fuel should configure the MySQL
transaction_isolation=READ-COMMITTED as it looks that this
mode is implicit for backends by Oslo.db because it is a
standard for DB transations.

Change-Id: Ib4d22e1cdfb177ce236a89e7a6292292018052fa
Closes-bug: #1438107
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/42/168842/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: transaction-isolation=READ-COMMITTED

commit_message:
Improve ec2-api gating jobs for rally testing

1. Enable tempest for rally gate. Only tempest preparation code has needed falvors creation -
flavors without disk(m1.nano for example). We need flavor without disk because only this can be
run with fakevirt driver due to bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1433994

2. Add calling hook script before running rally to setup specific things of third-party project.
For example - botocore. This library is absent in global requirements and can not be add to ec2-api
project. And global requirements is frozen now for adding new.

Change-Id: I9993c97ecb6900efefc8ae73107d8a06a9e6dcf6
